11243Transition Metal ChemistryTransition Met Chem0340-42851572-901XSpringer NetherlandsDordrechts11243-009-9268-y926810.1007/s11243-009-9268-yArticleSynthesis and characterization of zinc(II), copper(II) and cadmium(II) coordination polymers with tetrachloroterephthalate-based ligandsZhengChang-Ge1aLiSong1ZhangPei-Pei1WangWan-Xia1HongJian-Quan1QianQian-Li1ChenXiu-Ying1grid.258151.a0000000107081323School of Chemical and Material Engineering of Jiangnan University214122WuxiJiangsuPeople’s Republic of Chinacgzheng@jiangnan.edu.cn2182009102009347815820307200984200929720092182009© Springer Science+Business Media B.V. 20092009Abstract

Three complexes, namely Zn(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (1), Cu(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (2) and Cd(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (3) (BDC-Cl4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, py = pyridine) have been synthesized. Complexes (1) and (2) have been obtained using solvothermal methods. Both have a five-coordinate geometry with two bridging monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three pyridine ligands coordinated to the Zn(II) or Cu(II) atom. The tetrachloroterephthalate ligands bridge the adjacent Zn(II) or Cu(II) centers, giving zigzag chains. Complex (3) has also been crystallized, each Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms and three pyridyl nitrogen atoms. Two types of tetrachloroterephthalate ligand, featuring monodentate and bidentate carboxylates, connect the Cd(II) centers to form zigzag chains. All three complexes have been subjected to thermogravimetric analysis.

Metal–organic framework (MOF) materials are of great current interest due to their well-defined, low-density structures and enormous potential in applications such as gas storage [1–3], catalysis [4, 5] and small molecule sensing [6]. Among the reported series of MOFs, MOF-5 has been frequently considered as a potential commercial target for its stability and porosity [7]. In particular, MOF-5 was found to adsorb large amounts of hydrogen reversibly at low temperature and moderate pressures, approaching DOE targets for onboard vehicular hydrogen storage [8]. Generally, there are two main strategies to improve the hydrogen uptake for MOFs, namely increasing the binding energy of H2 to the network, and increasing the internal surface area and/or pore volume [9]. Recently, computer calculations have suggested that halogens such as chloride can enhance the adsorption of hydrogen molecules [10]. Therefore, MOF-5 structures with halogen substituents on the C6 ring should be of interest for potential applications in gas storage.

To date, there are few reports on polyhalogenated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligands, especially tetrachloroterephthalate. Here, we report three complexes with tetrachloroterephthalate as the ligand, namely Zn(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (1), Cu(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (2) and Cd(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (3).

Experimental

Tetrachloroterephthalic acid was purchased commercially from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. (SCRC). 2,3,5,6-Tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester was synthesized and purified by recrystallization. All other reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was performed on a Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4,000–500 cm−1) were recorded with an ABB Bomem FTLA 2000-104 spectrophotometer on KBr disks.

Synthesis of [Zn(C<sub>8</sub>Cl<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)(py)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

A mixture of 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester (0.0664 g, 0.20 mmol) and ZnCl2 (0.0136 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol (3 mL), pyridine (3 mL) and H2O (6 mL) was placed in a sealed vial (20 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days, then allowed to cool. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals were filtered off, dried in air and collected in 64% yield (on the basis of Zn). Anal. calcd. for C23H15Cl4N3O4Zn: C, 45.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. Found: C, 45.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,457(m), 1,649(s), 1,618(s), 1,447(m), 1,331(s), 1,229(m), 1,043(m), 839(w), 761(m), 702(s), 630(m).

Synthesis of [Cu(C<sub>8</sub>Cl<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)(py)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex (2) was obtained with CuSO4·5H2O (0.0250 g, 0.1 mmol) as a reactant by a procedure similar to Complex (1). Green block-shaped crystals were obtained in a yield of 57% based on Cu. Anal. calcd. for C23H15Cl4N3O4Cu: C, 45.8%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. Found: C, 45.8%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,465(m), 1,698(s), 1,485(m), 1,446(m), 1,383(s), 1,328(s), 1,113(m), 843(w), 765(m), 702(s), 620(m).

Synthesis of [Cd(C<sub>8</sub>F<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)(py)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

This complex was synthesized by slow vapor diffusion at room temperature. In a small vial, tetrachloroterephthalic acid (0.090 g, 0.30 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0463 g, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of methanol (3 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) at room temperature. The vial was then put into a larger vial containing pyridine (4 mL), which was sealed and left undisturbed for 7 days at room temperature. The yield was 65% based on Cd. Anal. calcd. for C23H15CdCl4N3O4: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.5%. Found: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.4%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,700–2,500(m), 1,601.7(s), 1,492.0(w)m, 1,437.6(s), 1,389.8(s), 1,346.8(s), 1,222.0(w), 1,119.0(w), 1,073.2(w), 1,049.6(w), 865.1(w), 757.3(w), 693.6(w), 634.8(s).

X-ray crystallography and structure determination

The diffraction data for all three complexes were collected at 293 K on a BRUKER SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data were collected with ϕ and ω-scan techniques in the range of 2.37° ≤ θ ≤ 25.04°, 2.35° ≤ θ ≤ 25.00° and 2.20° ≤ θ ≤ 25.05°, respectively. Empirical absorption correction was applied for all data. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 package. Platon Squeeze procedure was used in modeling of the disordered solvent molecule in complex (2). The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1.

Results and discussion

In the reaction for complexes (1) and (2), 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester was hydrolyzed to give the tetrachloroterephthalate ligand under the hydrothermal conditions. Such an in situ hydrolysis strategy has been extensively used for the synthesis of a variety of coordination polymers [11].

Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that complex (1) has a 1D polymeric structure crystallizing in the monoclinic space group C2/c. A selection of bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are given in Table 2. Complex (1) has a five-coordinate geometry with two monodentate tetrachloroterephthalates, and three pyridine ligands coordinated to the Zn(II) center (Fig. 1). The donors, O1, O2 from two tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and N1 from a pyridine molecule, form an equatorial plane with the axial positions occupied by two pyridine molecules. The axial Zn1–N1 bond distance is 2.081 Å, which is shorter than the Zn1–N2 distance of 2.375 Å. The Zn1–O2 distance is 1.925 Å, shorter than the Zn–O distances in the reported MOF-5, 2.071(6) and 2.135(7) Å, respectively [12]. The tetrachloroterephthalates have a cis disposition to each other. Complex (1) is composed of only one type of tetrachloroterephthalate ligand, in which both carboxylates are monodentate. These monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands connect alternately to the adjacent Zn(II) atom units into a one-dimensional zigzag chains. Intermolecular C–H···O and C–H···Zn hydrogen bonds result in extended networks in complex (1) (Fig. 2).

Complex (2) has a five-coordinate geometry with the Cu(II) atom coordinated to two monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three pyridine molecules (Fig. 3). Complex (2) also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and adopts a 1D coordination network structure, similar to complex (1). Selected bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are shown in Table 2. The O2–Cu1–O2#2 angle is 99.21(18)°, and the N1–Cu1–N2 angle is 91.38(5)°. The bond lengths around the Cu(II) are 2.0157(17) Å for Cu1–N1, 2.068(2) Å for Cu1–N2 and 2.1097(14) Å for Cu1–O2. These values can be compared to the reported Cu(II) complex of tetrafluoroterephthalate-based ligand, in which the bond lengths are 2.0236(16) Å for Cu–N and 2.0609(12) Å for Cu–O [13]. As for complex (1), the extended network of complex (2) is achieved via intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds (Fig. 4).

In complex (3), the Cd(II) atom in the asymmetric unit adopts a six-coordinate geometry (Fig. 5). Selected bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are tabulated in Table 2. Each Cd(II) center is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from the two tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three nitrogen atoms of three pyridine ligands. The axial positions are occupied by two nitrogen atoms of pyridine ligands, with a N1–Cd1–N2 angle of 89.33°. Three nitrogen atoms from the pyridine ligands coordinate asymmetrically to Cd(II) with Cd–N distances of 2.361, 2.348 and 2.352 Å, respectively. The O1–Cd1–O3 angle is 90.17(7)°, and the O1–Cd1–O4 angle is 143.26(7)°. There are two kinds of tetrachloroterephthalate ligands in complex (3); one is monodentate and the other is bidentate. The two kinds of tetrachloroterephthalate ligands connect alternately to the adjacent Cd(II) atoms to give one-dimensional zigzag chains. The C–H···O and C–H···Cl hydrogen interactions stabilize the structure to form the three-dimensional (3D) network as shown in Fig. 6.

Thermal decomposition

TG curves of complexes (1)–(3) using a heating rate of 20 °C/min are illustrated in Figs. 7, 8 and 9, respectively. The TG curve of complex (1) shows three mass loss stages in the range of 100–600 °C. The first two mass losses correspond to two pyridines, loss of the third pyridine and tetrachloroterephthalate commences at 240 °C. The TG curves of complexes (2) and (3) show two main mass loss stages. In complex (2), the first mass loss corresponds to one pyridine. The other two pyridines with tetrachloroterephthalate are lost from 220 °C. In complex (3), the first mass loss is assigned to two pyridines. The third pyridine with tetrachloroterephthalate begins loss at 250 °C.

Conclusion

We have prepared three new Zn(II), Cu(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with tetrachloroterephthalate-based ligands via two methods. The Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes were synthesized by solvothermal methods using dimethyl tetrachloroterephthalate as precursor. The Cd(II) complex was obtained with tetrachloroterephthalic acid by slow solvent diffusion. With five-coordinate geometries, the Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes have one-dimensional zigzag chain polymer structures with the carboxylate groups in monodentate chelate modes. The Cd(II) complex also shows a one-dimensional zigzag chain but in bidentate modes with a six-coordinate geometry.

Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic data Center and are available on request quoting the deposition numbers CCDC 706729, 706730 and 706429 for complexes (1)–(3), respectively.

elements.content: Three complexes, namely Zn(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (1), Cu(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (2) and Cd(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (3) (BDC-Cl4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, py = pyridine) have been synthesized. Complexes (1) and (2) have been obtained using solvothermal methods. Both have a five-coordinate geometry with two bridging monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three pyridine ligands coordinated to the Zn(II) or Cu(II) atom. The tetrachloroterephthalate ligands bridge the adjacent Zn(II) or Cu(II) centers, giving zigzag chains. Complex (3) has also been crystallized, each Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms and three pyridyl nitrogen atoms. Two types of tetrachloroterephthalate ligand, featuring monodentate and bidentate carboxylates, connect the Cd(II) centers to form zigzag chains. All three complexes have been subjected to thermogravimetric analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Three complexes, namely Zn(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (1), Cu(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (2) and Cd(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (3) (BDC-Cl4 = 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, py = pyridine) have been synthesized. Complexes (1) and (2) have been obtained using solvothermal methods. Both have a five-coordinate geometry with two bridging monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three pyridine ligands coordinated to the Zn(II) or Cu(II) atom. The tetrachloroterephthalate ligands bridge the adjacent Zn(II) or Cu(II) centers, giving zigzag chains. Complex (3) has also been crystallized, each Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms and three pyridyl nitrogen atoms. Two types of tetrachloroterephthalate ligand, featuring monodentate and bidentate carboxylates, connect the Cd(II) centers to form zigzag chains. All three complexes have been subjected to thermogravimetric analysis.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) materials are of great current interest due to their well-defined, low-density structures and enormous potential in applications such as gas storage [1–3], catalysis [4, 5] and small molecule sensing [6]. Among the reported series of MOFs, MOF-5 has been frequently considered as a potential commercial target for its stability and porosity [7]. In particular, MOF-5 was found to adsorb large amounts of hydrogen reversibly at low temperature and moderate pressures, approaching DOE targets for onboard vehicular hydrogen storage [8]. Generally, there are two main strategies to improve the hydrogen uptake for MOFs, namely increasing the binding energy of H2 to the network, and increasing the internal surface area and/or pore volume [9]. Recently, computer calculations have suggested that halogens such as chloride can enhance the adsorption of hydrogen molecules [10]. Therefore, MOF-5 structures with halogen substituents on the C6 ring should be of interest for potential applications in gas storage.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials are of great current interest due to their well-defined, low-density structures and enormous potential in applications such as gas storage [1-3], catalysis [4, 5] and small molecule sensing [6]. Among the reported series of MOFs, MOF-5 has been frequently considered as a potential commercial target for its stability and porosity [7]. In particular, MOF-5 was found to adsorb large amounts of hydrogen reversibly at low temperature and moderate pressures, approaching DOE targets for onboard vehicular hydrogen storage [8]. Generally, there are two main strategies to improve the hydrogen uptake for MOFs, namely increasing the binding energy of H2 to the network, and increasing the internal surface area and/or pore volume [9]. Recently, computer calculations have suggested that halogens such as chloride can enhance the adsorption of hydrogen molecules [10]. Therefore, MOF-5 structures with halogen substituents on the C6 ring should be of interest for potential applications in gas storage.

elements.content: To date, there are few reports on polyhalogenated 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate ligands, especially tetrachloroterephthalate. Here, we report three complexes with tetrachloroterephthalate as the ligand, namely Zn(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (1), Cu(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (2) and Cd(BDC-Cl4)(py)3 (3).

elements.content: Tetrachloroterephthalic acid was purchased commercially from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. (SCRC). 2,3,5,6-Tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester was synthesized and purified by recrystallization. All other reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was performed on a Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4,000–500 cm−1) were recorded with an ABB Bomem FTLA 2000-104 spectrophotometer on KBr disks.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Tetrachloroterephthalic acid was purchased commercially from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co, Ltd. (SCRC). 2,3,5,6-Tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester was synthesized and purified by recrystallization. All other reagents and solvents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analysis was performed on a Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4,000-500 cm-1) were recorded with an ABB Bomem FTLA 2000-104 spectrophotometer on KBr disks.

elements.content: A mixture of 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester (0.0664 g, 0.20 mmol) and ZnCl2 (0.0136 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol (3 mL), pyridine (3 mL) and H2O (6 mL) was placed in a sealed vial (20 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days, then allowed to cool. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals were filtered off, dried in air and collected in 64% yield (on the basis of Zn). Anal. calcd. for C23H15Cl4N3O4Zn: C, 45.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. Found: C, 45.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,457(m), 1,649(s), 1,618(s), 1,447(m), 1,331(s), 1,229(m), 1,043(m), 839(w), 761(m), 702(s), 630(m).

elements.content: This complex was synthesized by slow vapor diffusion at room temperature. In a small vial, tetrachloroterephthalic acid (0.090 g, 0.30 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0463 g, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of methanol (3 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) at room temperature. The vial was then put into a larger vial containing pyridine (4 mL), which was sealed and left undisturbed for 7 days at room temperature. The yield was 65% based on Cd. Anal. calcd. for C23H15CdCl4N3O4: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.5%. Found: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.4%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,700–2,500(m), 1,601.7(s), 1,492.0(w)m, 1,437.6(s), 1,389.8(s), 1,346.8(s), 1,222.0(w), 1,119.0(w), 1,073.2(w), 1,049.6(w), 865.1(w), 757.3(w), 693.6(w), 634.8(s).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Cd(C8F4O4)(py)3] (3)

This complex was synthesized by slow vapor diffusion at room temperature. In a small vial, tetrachloroterephthalic acid (0.090 g, 0.30 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.0463 g, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of methanol (3 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) at room temperature. The vial was then put into a larger vial containing pyridine (4 mL), which was sealed and left undisturbed for 7 days at room temperature. The yield was 65% based on Cd. Anal. calcd. for C23H15CdCl4N3O4: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.5%. Found: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.4%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3,700-2,500(m), 1,601.7(s), 1,492.0(w)m, 1,437.6(s), 1,389.8(s), 1,346.8(s), 1,222.0(w), 1,119.0(w), 1,073.2(w), 1,049.6(w), 865.1(w), 757.3(w), 693.6(w), 634.8(s).

elements.content: The diffraction data for all three complexes were collected at 293 K on a BRUKER SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data were collected with ϕ and ω-scan techniques in the range of 2.37° ≤ θ ≤ 25.04°, 2.35° ≤ θ ≤ 25.00° and 2.20° ≤ θ ≤ 25.05°, respectively. Empirical absorption correction was applied for all data. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 package. Platon Squeeze procedure was used in modeling of the disordered solvent molecule in complex (2). The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography and structure determination

The diffraction data for all three complexes were collected at 293 K on a BRUKER SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Ka radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Intensity data were collected with ϕ and ω-scan techniques in the range of 2.37° ≤ θ ≤ 25.04°, 2.35° ≤ θ ≤ 25.00° and 2.20° ≤ θ ≤ 25.05°, respectively. Empirical absorption correction was applied for all data. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least squares on F2 using the SHELXTL-97 package. Platon Squeeze procedure was used in modeling of the disordered solvent molecule in complex (2). The crystallographic data are listed in Table 1.

In the reaction for complexes (1) and (2), 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester was hydrolyzed to give the tetrachloroterephthalate ligand under the hydrothermal conditions. Such an in situ hydrolysis strategy has been extensively used for the synthesis of a variety of coordination polymers [11].
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

In the reaction for complexes (1) and (2), 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester was hydrolyzed to give the tetrachloroterephthalate ligand under the hydrothermal conditions. Such an in situ hydrolysis strategy has been extensively used for the synthesis of a variety of coordination polymers [11].

elements.content: Single-crystal structure analysis reveals that complex (1) has a 1D polymeric structure crystallizing in the monoclinic space group C2/c. A selection of bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are given in Table 2. Complex (1) has a five-coordinate geometry with two monodentate tetrachloroterephthalates, and three pyridine ligands coordinated to the Zn(II) center (Fig. 1). The donors, O1, O2 from two tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and N1 from a pyridine molecule, form an equatorial plane with the axial positions occupied by two pyridine molecules. The axial Zn1–N1 bond distance is 2.081 Å, which is shorter than the Zn1–N2 distance of 2.375 Å. The Zn1–O2 distance is 1.925 Å, shorter than the Zn–O distances in the reported MOF-5, 2.071(6) and 2.135(7) Å, respectively [12]. The tetrachloroterephthalates have a cis disposition to each other. Complex (1) is composed of only one type of tetrachloroterephthalate ligand, in which both carboxylates are monodentate. These monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands connect alternately to the adjacent Zn(II) atom units into a one-dimensional zigzag chains. Intermolecular C–H···O and C–H···Zn hydrogen bonds result in extended networks in complex (1) (Fig. 2).

A selection of bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are given in Table 2. Complex (1) has a five-coordinate geometry with two monodentate tetrachloroterephthalates, and three pyridine ligands coordinated to the Zn(II) center (Fig. 1). The donors, O1, O2 from two tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and N1 from a pyridine molecule, form an equatorial plane with the axial positions occupied by two pyridine molecules. The axial Zn1-N1 bond distance is 2.081 Å, which is shorter than the Zn1-N2 distance of 2.375 Å. The Zn1-O2 distance is 1.925 Å, shorter than the Zn-O distances in the reported MOF-5, 2.071(6) and 2.135(7) Å, respectively [12]. The tetrachloroterephthalates have a cis disposition to each other. Complex (1) is composed of only one type of tetrachloroterephthalate ligand, in which both carboxylates are monodentate. These monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands connect alternately to the adjacent Zn(II) atom units into a one-dimensional zigzag chains. Intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅Zn hydrogen bonds result in extended networks in complex (1) (Fig. 2).

elements.content: Complex (2) has a five-coordinate geometry with the Cu(II) atom coordinated to two monodentate tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three pyridine molecules (Fig. 3). Complex (2) also crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and adopts a 1D coordination network structure, similar to complex (1). Selected bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are shown in Table 2. The O2–Cu1–O2#2 angle is 99.21(18)°, and the N1–Cu1–N2 angle is 91.38(5)°. The bond lengths around the Cu(II) are 2.0157(17) Å for Cu1–N1, 2.068(2) Å for Cu1–N2 and 2.1097(14) Å for Cu1–O2. These values can be compared to the reported Cu(II) complex of tetrafluoroterephthalate-based ligand, in which the bond lengths are 2.0236(16) Å for Cu–N and 2.0609(12) Å for Cu–O [13]. As for complex (1), the extended network of complex (2) is achieved via intermolecular C–H···O hydrogen bonds (Fig. 4).

The bond lengths around the Cu(II) are 2.0157(17) Å for Cu1-N1, 2.068(2) Å for Cu1-N2 and 2.1097(14) Å for Cu1-O2. These values can be compared to the reported Cu(II) complex of tetrafluoroterephthalate-based ligand, in which the bond lengths are 2.0236(16) Å for Cu-N and 2.0609(12) Å for Cu-O [13]. As for complex (1), the extended network of complex (2) is achieved via intermolecular C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds (Fig. 4).

elements.content: In complex (3), the Cd(II) atom in the asymmetric unit adopts a six-coordinate geometry (Fig. 5). Selected bond distances, angles and hydrogen bonds are tabulated in Table 2. Each Cd(II) center is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from the two tetrachloroterephthalate ligands and three nitrogen atoms of three pyridine ligands. The axial positions are occupied by two nitrogen atoms of pyridine ligands, with a N1–Cd1–N2 angle of 89.33°. Three nitrogen atoms from the pyridine ligands coordinate asymmetrically to Cd(II) with Cd–N distances of 2.361, 2.348 and 2.352 Å, respectively. The O1–Cd1–O3 angle is 90.17(7)°, and the O1–Cd1–O4 angle is 143.26(7)°. There are two kinds of tetrachloroterephthalate ligands in complex (3); one is monodentate and the other is bidentate. The two kinds of tetrachloroterephthalate ligands connect alternately to the adjacent Cd(II) atoms to give one-dimensional zigzag chains. The C–H···O and C–H···Cl hydrogen interactions stabilize the structure to form the three-dimensional (3D) network as shown in Fig. 6.

elements.content: TG curves of complexes (1)–(3) using a heating rate of 20 °C/min are illustrated in Figs. 7, 8 and 9, respectively. The TG curve of complex (1) shows three mass loss stages in the range of 100–600 °C. The first two mass losses correspond to two pyridines, loss of the third pyridine and tetrachloroterephthalate commences at 240 °C. The TG curves of complexes (2) and (3) show two main mass loss stages. In complex (2), the first mass loss corresponds to one pyridine. The other two pyridines with tetrachloroterephthalate are lost from 220 °C. In complex (3), the first mass loss is assigned to two pyridines. The third pyridine with tetrachloroterephthalate begins loss at 250 °C.

The TG curves of complexes (2) and (3) show two main mass loss stages. In complex (2), the first mass loss corresponds to one pyridine. The other two pyridines with tetrachloroterephthalate are lost from 220 °C. In complex (3), the first mass loss is assigned to two pyridines. The third pyridine with tetrachloroterephthalate begins loss at 250 °C.

elements.content: We have prepared three new Zn(II), Cu(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with tetrachloroterephthalate-based ligands via two methods. The Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes were synthesized by solvothermal methods using dimethyl tetrachloroterephthalate as precursor. The Cd(II) complex was obtained with tetrachloroterephthalic acid by slow solvent diffusion. With five-coordinate geometries, the Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes have one-dimensional zigzag chain polymer structures with the carboxylate groups in monodentate chelate modes. The Cd(II) complex also shows a one-dimensional zigzag chain but in bidentate modes with a six-coordinate geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have prepared three new Zn(II), Cu(II) and Cd(II) coordination polymers with tetrachloroterephthalate-based ligands via two methods. The Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes were synthesized by solvothermal methods using dimethyl tetrachloroterephthalate as precursor. The Cd(II) complex was obtained with tetrachloroterephthalic acid by slow solvent diffusion. With five-coordinate geometries, the Zn(II) and Cu(II) complexes have one-dimensional zigzag chain polymer structures with the carboxylate groups in monodentate chelate modes. The Cd(II) complex also shows a one-dimensional zigzag chain but in bidentate modes with a six-coordinate geometry.

A mixture of 2,3,5,6-tetrachloro-1,4-dimethyl ester (0.0664 g, 0.20 mmol) and ZnCl2 (0.0136 g, 0.10 mmol) in methanol (3 mL), pyridine (3 mL) and H2O (6 mL) was placed in a sealed vial (20 mL) and heated at 120 °C for 3 days, then allowed to cool. The resulting colorless block-shaped crystals were filtered off, dried in air and collected in 64% yield (on the basis of Zn). Anal. calcd. for C23H15Cl4N3O4Zn: C, 45.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. Found: C, 45.7%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,457(m), 1,649(s), 1,618(s), 1,447(m), 1,331(s), 1,229(m), 1,043(m), 839(w), 761(m), 702(s), 630(m).

Synthesis of [Cu(C<sub>8</sub>Cl<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)(py)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>2</bold>)

Complex (2) was obtained with CuSO4·5H2O (0.0250 g, 0.1 mmol) as a reactant by a procedure similar to Complex (1). Green block-shaped crystals were obtained in a yield of 57% based on Cu. Anal. calcd. for C23H15Cl4N3O4Cu: C, 45.8%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. Found: C, 45.8%; H, 2.5%; N, 7.0%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,465(m), 1,698(s), 1,485(m), 1,446(m), 1,383(s), 1,328(s), 1,113(m), 843(w), 765(m), 702(s), 620(m).

Synthesis of [Cd(C<sub>8</sub>F<sub>4</sub>O<sub>4</sub>)(py)<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

This complex was synthesized by slow vapor diffusion at room temperature. In a small vial, tetrachloroterephthalic acid (0.090 g, 0.30 mmol) and Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.0463 g, 0.15 mmol) were dissolved in a mixture of methanol (3 mL) and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (1 mL) at room temperature. The vial was then put into a larger vial containing pyridine (4 mL), which was sealed and left undisturbed for 7 days at room temperature. The yield was 65% based on Cd. Anal. calcd. for C23H15CdCl4N3O4: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.5%. Found: C, 42.4%; H, 2.3%; N, 6.4%. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3,700–2,500(m), 1,601.7(s), 1,492.0(w)m, 1,437.6(s), 1,389.8(s), 1,346.8(s), 1,222.0(w), 1,119.0(w), 1,073.2(w), 1,049.6(w), 865.1(w), 757.3(w), 693.6(w), 634.8(s).
